caption:
*faints at the sight of microplastics in blood* 😵🩸 Plastic particles were found in nearly 80% of people tested in a new study.

Researchers found the highest amount of PET (plastic code #1) which is commonly used in drinking bottles, as well as packaging for many cleaning and personal care products. The long-term impact on human health is unknown, but researchers are concerned as these particles can lodge into organs and microplastics have been shown to cause damage to human cells in the laboratory.

The best thing we can do is avoid plastic products that could leach into our food and beverages, and reduce single-use plastic consumption as it can contribute to microplastic pollution.

caption:
Many of us participate in what’s known as “wishcycling”. Though well-intended, it’s one of the biggest challenges facing the recycling industry.

From greasy pizza boxes to milk cartons, items that seem recyclable can contaminate whole loads of recyclable materials — making them impossible to process and can even clog up sorting machines. As a result, facilities often send trucks full of valuable material to landfilll. The plastic cup in this video, for example, is often recyclable. But even if this were an actual recycling bin, the leftover strawberries and ice could have contaminated the load.

Better education and clearer guidelines are needed to help combat confusion. It’s important to check locally to see what’s accepted by your program. Two rules of thumb that are applicable most places is ensuring items are 1) clean and dry, and 2) made of just one recyclable material.

What is your experience with recycling? ♻️ #GlobalRecyclingDay

caption:
A routine load of laundry could release millions of microplastics into our waterways and oceans. Because around 2/3rds of our clothing is synthetic, or a blend of synthetic and natural, it’s important to know which fabrics contain plastic and which don’t so we can take steps to reduce microplastic shedding 🤝

It’s virtually impossible to avoid, but there’s a couple of ways to reduce shedding in the wash:

1. Use a filter. A washing bag from @guppyfriend helps collect microplastic fibers before they make their way out and can even reduce shedding in the first place. There’s also external options that attach right to your washing machine.

2. Follow best washing practices: Wash less often and at lower temperatures to preserve fabrics. Reduce spin speeds and only wash full loads to limit friction. Air dry when possible.
